Peak Productivity

EagleView | Research and Design | 2018-2019

EagleView creates mapping and measurement products from aerial photos, relying on humans to review thousands of images for focus, cloud-cover, and anomalies. This labor-intensive process, with images displayed in an inhuman byte-block pattern, caused burnout. As one of many projects I tackled, I redesigned it to boost efficiency and standardize tasks, incorporating a system with AI to classify images and machine learning trained on human-reviewed data.

New Design

I led a redesign to accelerate common tasks and automate others using AI classification, making image selection and tagging faster and more standardized. Technicians embraced the design, noting it would streamline their work for higher-value tasks.

Legacy Design

The existing software was inefficient and user-unfriendly:

  • Controls were small, unlabeled icons.
  • Images were ordered by byte blocks, not adjacency.
  • Adjacent images were rarely grouped.

Research: Understanding User Needs

I sat with Geomatics QC technicians, observing their workflows and interviewing them on their actions and motivations. This hands-on approach revealed:

  • File names were only needed for selection, otherwise cluttering space.
  • Metadata mattered only in diagnostics.
  • Less than 1% of images were enlarged, though any could be selected.
  • Anomalous images needed review but were hard to find in the set.
  • Technicians rapidly scanned for visual anomalies.
  • Rejections required marking reasons, involving multiple clicks.
  • Byte-block order hindered selecting adjacent cloud-covered images.

Innovations

Driven by research, I introduced AI-enhanced solutions:

  • Organized images by six cameras and timestamps into a grid, easing group selection.
  • Enabled column selection to reject camera-affected series.
  • Allowed row selection by timestamp for similar benefits.
  • Added ‘line‘ selection for aerial motion-related anomalies.
  • Implemented community tags with autocomplete, refined by machine learning.
  • Sorted tagged images into review tabs using AI automation.

Selecting Columns, Rows, and Lines

Users can select single images, rows, columns, or lines efficiently for QC tasks.

The homepage, aided by AI classification, overviews active surveys with color-coded status and tooltips, sorted by tabs.

Enlarged images offer coverage data, enhanced by machine learning trained on human reviews.

Code Support

I suggested developer solutions, a rare step, to ensure the AI-driven design‘s implementation, supporting the Argentina team‘s capacity.

Style Guide

I created a simple style guide for consistent UI elements, aligning with AI features.
